Intro to Typescript

What Is Typescript?

“Typed superset of JS”

Transpiler

  • Compiles down to JS
  • Module bundling

Static Typing

  • Type checking at compile time
  • Actually optional

Why Typescript?

Easier to write and mantain Javascript projects (especially large ones)

Transpiler

  • Compile down to the target ES version
  • Bundle into the format you want
  • Syntactic sugar for interfaces, overloading, generics, etc

Static Typing

  • No need to write tests (or code) to check variable types
  • Provides inline documentation
  • Easy to get started and port legacy code

Linting

  • Catches more mistakes in your code (gaps in logic, etc)
  • Safer refactoring — guarantees all the pieces fit together

Popular & Well-Supported

  • Regular releases and active community
  • Babel, Electron, and others support TS now

Compiling Your First Program

$ npm install -g typescript
$ tsc app.ts
$ tsc app     # assumes .ts extension
$ tsc         # uses config
$ tsc -p src  # set the root folder
$ tsc -w      # watch for changes

app.ts

function greet(person) {
   return `Hello ${person}!`;
}
const name = 'John';
console.log(greet(name));
⇒

app.js

function greet(person) {
   return "Hello " + person + "!";
}
var name = 'John';
console.log(greet(name));

app.ts

function getName() {
   return Promise.resolve('John');
}
async function greetPerson() {
   let person = await getName();
   return `Hello ${person}!`;
}
console.log(greetPerson());
⇒

app.js

var __awaiter = (this && this.__awaiter) || function (thisArg, _arguments, P, generator) {
   // snip
};
var __generator = (this && this.__generator) || function (thisArg, body) {
   // snip
};
function getName() {
   return Promise.resolve('John');
}
function greetPerson() {
   return __awaiter(this, void 0, void 0, function () {
       var person;
       return __generator(this, function (_a) {
         // snip
       });
   });
}
console.log(greetPerson());
[] + [];



"hello" - 1;




function add(a,b) {
   return
       a + b;
}
⇒
[] + [];
// ^ Operator '+' cannot be applied to types 
//   'undefined[]' and 'undefined[]'.

"hello" - 1;
// ^ The left-hand side of an arithmetic operation must be of
//   type 'any', 'number' or an enum type.

function add(a, b) {
   return;
   a + b;
   // ^ Unreachable code detected.
}

Type Annotations

function greet(person: string) {
   return `Hello ${person}!`;
}
const name = 3;
console.log(greet(name));
⇒
function greet(person) {
   return "Hello " + person + "!";
}
var name = 3;
console.log(greet(name));
//                ^ Argument of type '3' is not assignable
//                  to parameter of type 'string'.

Basic Types

Primitives

let num: number;
let str: string;
let bool: boolean;
let u: undefined = undefined;
let n: null = null;

Arrays

let boolArray: boolean[];

Any

let notSure: any = 4;
notSure = "maybe a string instead";
notSure.ifItExists();

Functions

function getHello(name: string): string { return `Hello ${name}`; }
function warn(): void { alert("Warning!"); }
function error(): never { throw new Error("Error!"); }

Extended Types

Enum

enum Color {Red, Green, Blue}
let c: Color = Color.Green;

Union

let numOrString: number|string;

Optional Parameter

function getHello(firstName: string, lastName?: string): string {
   return `Hello ${firstName} ${lastName || ''}`;
}

Interface

interface Point {
   x: number;
   y: number;
   z?: number;
}

let p1: Point = {
   x: 1, y: 2, z: 3
}

class MyPoint implements Point {
 x: number; y: number;
}
let p: Point = new MyPoint();
⇒
var p1 = {
   x: 1, y: 2, z: 3
};
var MyPoint = (function () {
   function MyPoint() {
   }
   return MyPoint;
}());
var p2 = new MyPoint();

More Keywords

Readonly

interface Point {
   readonly x: number;
   readonly y: number;
}

Public/Private/Protected

class Animal {
   private name: string;
   constructor(theName: string) { this.name = theName; }
}
new Animal("Cat").name; // error!

Inference

Typescript can often figure out types by examining your code.

let x = 3;
let x = [0, 1, null];

So type annotations are only needed where you want to:

  • enforce a type,
  • or define a type when TS can't infer it.

Working With Types

Generics

Example syntax: Array<number> 

class Queue<T> {
   private data = [];
   push = (item: T) => this.data.push(item);
   pop = (): T => this.data.shift();
}
const queue = new Queue<number>();
queue.push(0);

“Casting” (Type Assertions)

Sometimes you know more about a variable’s type than TS does.

Use only to when you have to, because TS assumes you are correct in your assertion. 

function handler(event: Event) {
   let mouseEvent = event as MouseEvent; // preferred
   let mouseEvent = <MouseEvent>event;
}

3rd-Party Type Declarations (The Easy Way)

import * as $ from "jquery";

Use the DefinitelyTyped repository to find “high quality TypeScript type definitions.” 

$ npm install @types/jquery -D

TS will automatically use these @types modules.

Use microsoft.github.io/TypeSearch to search for modules.

3rd-Party Type Declarations (The Slightly Harder Way)

Create your own declarations in the .ts file, or a .d.ts declaration file (recommended). 

declare module "foobar"; // simply declare that a module exists
import * as f from "foobar";
/// <reference path="foobar.d.ts" />
import * as f from "foobar";

Look at other libraries’ declarations and the DT website for best practices.

Project Configuration

tsconfig.json

Add a tsconfig.json file to your project folder to configure the TS compiler.

  • Can start with empty {}
  • Run tsc --init to create a tsconfig.json .
  • TS will automatically look for and use a config file.

Specifying Files

{
   "files": [
       "core.ts",
       "sys.ts",
       "types.ts"
   ]
}
{
   "include": [
       "src/**/*"
   ],
   "exclude": [
       "node_modules",
       "**/*.spec.ts"
   ]
}

Compiler Options

{
 "compilerOptions": {
     "module": "commonjs",
     "noImplicitAny": true,
     "removeComments": true,
     "preserveConstEnums": true,
     "sourceMap": true
 }
}

Reference: www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html

Output Options

  • target: es3 (default), es5, es6, es2015, es2016, es2017, esnext
  • module: none, es6, commonjs, amd, system, umd
  • outFile: concatenate and emit to a single file
  • outDir: output folder
  • removeComments: strips comments except those beginning with /*!
  • declaration: output a .d.ts file
  • sourceMap: output a .map file

Included Declarations

{
 "compilerOptions": {
   "lib": [
     "es5",
     "es2015",
     "es2016",
     "es2017",
     "esnext",
     "dom",
     "dom.iterable",
     "webworker",
     "scripthost",
     // others ...
   ]
 }
}

If not specified, TS will include libs based on the target version.

Migration Options

{
 "compilerOptions": {
   "allowJs": true,
   "checkJs": true
 }
}

Type annotations are not allowed in JS files; only checks that ES is valid.

Stricter Checking

Enable these after a migration, or from the start, for tighter type checking.

  • alwaysStrict: parse in strict mode and emit "use strict"
  • strictNullChecks: null and undefined must be explicitly added to types
  • noImplicitAny: error if any expression or declaration has an implied any type
  • noImplicitThis: catches instances where this is bound to the global context
  • strict: all of the above

Dev/Build Tools

  • IDEs
    • Show compile errors, have autocomplete, go to declarations, etc
    • Built-in to VSCode; supported in others
  • Frameworks
    • Built-in to Angular & Aurelia
    • Extensions available for other frameworks (React, Vue, etc)
    • TS has JSX support
    • Many quick-start & boilerplate projects
  • Plugins – gulp, webpack loader (ts-loader), browserify (tsify)
  • Linting
    • TS has some built-in linting options
    • tslint
    • typescript-eslint-parser

Gotchas

  • It’s harder than writing plain old Javascript!
    • New syntax to learn
    • Must keep track of type declarations in addition to JS variable declarations
    • In general, have to know more about how the compiler works
  • TS annotations live inside your JS code.
    • Look at alternatives (Flow, Closure) if you want annotations outside your code.
  • If you don’t like OOP, the extra OO stuff in TS might turn you off.
  • Errors are descriptive, but may contain perplexing terminology (e.g. "ambient module").
  • Module resolution is still tricky in JS.
    • Multiple module formats (ES6, CJS) with varying support across platforms
    • import vs require module resolution
    • export is different based on the module format
  • May be more work to migrate existing JS codebases than Flow.

Thanks

www.typescriptlang.org

TypeScript Deep Dive has nice Tips section, Common Errors section, migration guide
